Lack enough support: The claim of there being more than 300,000 infected with the novel coronavirus in China lacks sufficient evidence or data to support it. The expert mentions that the Chinese health authorities had recorded a total of 20,438 confirmed cases as of February 3, 2020.
Problematic assumption: The claim assumes that all Chinese nationals returning from the Lunar New Year festival in China are infected with the coronavirus, which is a problematic assumption. There is no evidence provided to support this assumption.
Contradict fact: The claim contradicts the fact that as of February 4, 2020, only 427 deaths have been reported due to the new strain of coronavirus, as reported by AFP. The claim of more than 300,000 infected contradicts this official data.
Understate: There is no evidence of understating bias in the provided claim.
Exaggerate: The claim may have an element of exaggeration by stating that over 300,000 Chinese are already infected with the coronavirus. This number is significantly higher than the officially reported cases.
Falters at times: There is no evidence of the claim faltering at times in the provided information.
Exist alternative explanation: The claim does not provide any alternative explanations for the reported number of infected individuals.
